Known as 'The Bird Psalter', this psalter includes the names of several West Country saints and was probably associated with Winchcombe or Gloucester. It takes its name from the fact that it depicts some 27 species of bird. Most of them are small, but carefully drawn, and they differ from those appearing in East Anglian psalters in that here they are not concentrated in a few places but scattered throughout the psalter. In addition to birds, there are men fighting and female figures playing musical instruments. A man is shown aiming a bow and arrow at a bird, and there is a large butterfly close by.
Dated c.1280-90, it may have been made for the marriage of Prince Alphonso (d.1284), heir of Edward I, to Margaret of Holland, since the arms of Holland occur in the manuscript.
